customData.content: 59-year-old female presented to the emergency department with new onset of seizures and abdominal pain. Past medical history significant for essential hypertension.

HPI.summary: 59-year-old female presented to the emergency department with new onset of seizures and abdominal pain.

customData.content: Bevacizumab treatment started. Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody that works as a chimeric VEGF receptor, blocking VEGF and preventing it from binding to VEGFR.

Diagnosed with Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM) 11 months prior to presentation, during evaluation for seizures. Received six weeks of low-dose radiation with concomitant temozolomide (115mg/day oral daily), discontinued due to refractory pancytopenia.
Patient complained of significant abdominal pain the night before presentation.

HPI.summary: Patient complained of significant abdominal pain the night before presentation.

customData.content: Three seizure episodes en route to the hospital, treated with benzodiazepines in the emergency room. Physical exam: abdominal tenderness with distention, rigidity, and guarding alongside neurological findings. Labs: low bicarbonate (19 mEq/L, normal range: 23-29 mEq/L) and mild elevation of high sensitivity troponin I (71 pg/mL, normal range: 0-12 pg/mL). CT scan of the head showed the right frontal and temporal lobe masses with a stable subfalcine shift of 7.0 mm.

HPI.summary: Three seizure episodes en route to the hospital

imaging.finding: right frontal and temporal lobe masses with a stable subfalcine shift of 7.0 mm

physical_exam.finding: abdominal tenderness with distention, rigidity, and guarding

customData.content: CT imaging of the abdomen revealed a large amount of retroperitoneal air, and some intraperitoneal air extending to the mediastinum. Distal colonic perforation with stool material outside of the colon in the pelvis and a sizable pelvic fluid collection was suspected. Colonic perforation was suspected to be at the descending colon/sigmoid colon junction, where the colon appeared somewhat thickened. No evidence of hemorrhage or obstructive hydrocephalus was found.

imaging.finding: Large amount of retroperitoneal air, some intraperitoneal air extending to the mediastinum. Distal colonic perforation with stool material outside of the colon in the pelvis and a sizable pelvic fluid collection was suspected. Colonic perforation was suspected to be at the descending colon/sigmoid colon junction, where the colon appeared somewhat thickened. No evidence of hemorrhage or obstructive hydrocephalus was found.

customData.content: Old CT scan of the abdomen showed a large diverticulum at the site of perforation. CT Scan Abdomen and Pelvis without contrast showed air in the peritoneum from Intestinal perforation. CT Scan Abdomen and Pelvis without contrast: Air in the peritoneum due to intestinal perforation. Air under the liver from intestinal perforation.

imaging.finding: large diverticulum at the site of perforation
air in the peritoneum from Intestinal perforation
Air in the peritoneum due to intestinal perforation
Air under the liver from intestinal perforation

diagnoses.label: Diverticulum of colon without mention of hemorrhage

customData.content: Stat consultation with the surgical team was obtained, and the patient's condition was discussed with the patient's oncologist and husband.
Comfort care was initiated per patient's wishes. Surgery was not considered due to the probability of poor wound healing.
Patient died in the hospital a couple of days into hospitalization.

data.content: Initiation of Bevacizumab treatment for the patient.
Patient's history of Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM) and prior treatment with radiation and temozolomide.
Patient's complaint of significant abdominal pain the night before presentation.

Patient experienced three seizure episodes en route to the hospital, treated with benzodiazepines. Physical exam revealed abdominal tenderness with distention, rigidity, and guarding, alongside neurological findings. Labs showed low bicarbonate and mild elevation of high sensitivity troponin I. CT scan of the head showed right frontal and temporal lobe masses with a stable subfalcine shift.

CT imaging of the abdomen revealed a large amount of retroperitoneal air, and some intraperitoneal air extending to the mediastinum. Distal colonic perforation with stool material outside of the colon in the pelvis and a sizable pelvic fluid collection was suspected.

Review of old CT scan of the abdomen showed a large diverticulum at the site of perforation. Current CT Scan Abdomen and Pelvis without contrast showed air in the peritoneum from Intestinal perforation.
Stat consultation with the surgical team was obtained, and the patient's condition was discussed with the patient's oncologist and husband.
Comfort care was initiated per patient's wishes. Surgery was not considered due to the probability of poor wound healing.
